fullText:
https://www.wsj.com/articles/harmony-review-barry-manilow-broadway-bruce-sussman-comedian-harmonists-germany-world-war-ii-musical-72163639

Steven Telsey, Blake Roman, Danny Kornfeld, Chip Zien, Eric Peters, Sean Bell and Zal Owen Photo: Julieta Cervantes

It’s no secret that the musical “Harmony” has been a longtime passion project for its authors, the famed pop fixture Barry Manilow and his songwriting partner Bruce Sussman. The show made its debut more than a quarter century ago in Southern California at the La Jolla Playhouse, was subsequently produced at other regional theaters, finally made it to off-Broadway last year, and now caps its long journey with an arrival on Broadway.

dtliExcerpt: Timely it may sadly be, but a theatrical triumph it still isn’t. I reviewed the show back in 1997, and while it is changed and improved, it rarely rises above a level of admirable, hard-working professionalism.
bwwExcerpt: Timely it may sadly be, but a theatrical triumph it still isn’t. I reviewed the show back in 1997, and while it is changed and improved, it rarely rises above a level of admirable, hard-working professionalism. The score, with music by Mr. Manilow and lyrics by Mr. Sussman, is appealingly various—influences range from Gilbert and Sullivan to cantorial melodies to Kurt Weill to standard contemporary Broadway balladry. (There is even a salsa-flavored song that seems to consciously evoke “Copacaban
showScoreExcerpt: Mr. Manilow's score is pleasant enough, with some genuinely moving moments, but the musical feels more like a historical pageant than a fully realized work of musical theater.
